text: 52 TH E HISTOR Y advantage, insomuch that, on the day ensuing the ides of January, they formed a resolution to take Otho under their care, as he returned from supper, and, with- out further delay, proclaim him emperor. This project, however, did not take effect. In the darkness of the night, and the con- fusion inseparable from it, no man could answer for the consequences. The city was full of soldiers; and among men in- flamed with liquor, no union, no con- certed measure, could be expected. The traitors desisted from their purpose, but with no public motive. The general wel- fare made no impression on men, who had conspired to imbrue their hands in the blood of their sovereign. What they chiefly feared was, that the first who offered himself to the troops from Ger- many and Pannonia, might by those strangers, and in the tumult of the dark, be mistaken for Otho, and saluted by the title of emperor.
